page.title: 03THE CHURCH IN DOWN ST MARY
page.content: The church was built in the 12th century at the crossing place of two ancient roads. The door way is an example of early Norman work with small stained glass windows on either side. Just above the door is a picture of Daniel in the lion's den. The inner arch is the oldest of the arches and one of the few Saxon remains found in the county. The church is very well built although much of it was rebuilt in 1871. Inside there are lovely carved bench ends. All the windows are stained glass and mostly are of Mary and Christ. The screen separates the nave from the chancel.
